response:
<<<api>>>: java.util.Collections.min
<<<code>>>: List<Entry> test = new ArrayList<Entry>();
test.add(new Entry(20, 0));
test.add(new Entry(5, 0));
test.add(new Entry(15, 0));
Entry minimum = Collections.min(test);
Entry maximum = Collections.max(test);
<<<explanation>>>: The issue with using `Collections.min(test)` is that `Entry` is not a valid substitute for the bounded parameter `<T extends Object & Comparable<? super T>>`. To fix this, you can define the `Entry` class as `Comparable` and implement the `compareTo()` method. Then you can use `Collections.min(test)` to get the minimum `Entry` in the list. Similarly, you can use `Collections.max(test)` to get the maximum `Entry`.
